Structures and Functions of the HOOF
Comparative anatomy
1. Develop an in-depth knowledge and recognition of the 
anatomical structure and composition of the equine hoof and its 
associated structures. 
2. Describe the formation and growth of hoof wall and weight 
bearing mechanism. 
3. Compare and contrast the normal equine foot anatomy with 
that of cloven hoofed animals.
4. Relate the knowledge and recognition of hoof anatomy to 
farriery with particular reference to hoof trimming and shoe 
placement.

Dermis (corium)
• Covers DP and digital cushion
• Blood and nerve supply
• Sensitive
• Supplies germinative layer
Germinative layer:
• Produces epidermis
• Active in 2 areas only
– Coronary band
– Solar surface

Dermal papillae

Coronary band
• Dermis formed into conical 
shaped papillae
• Produce epidermis in the form of 
tubes of keratin
• Extend distally towards ground
• Grow 5-6mm / ¼ inch per month
• Gaps filled by intertubular horn
• Form hoof wall
• Weight bearing surface

• Dermis fused to DP
• Surface of dermis forms vertical ridges = laminae

– Secondary = microscopic

Hoof wall:
• Epidermal horn tubes glide distally
